message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Schizophrenia disorder, as he hears voices and has delusions of persecution. The symptoms have lasted for more than 6 months, which differentiates it from Brief psychotic disorder. The urine toxicology test is negative, ruling out Substance-induced psychosis. Schizophreniform disorder has similar symptoms but lasts for less than 6 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest schizophrenia disorder, including auditory hallucinations, delusions of persecution, and disorganized behavior. The duration of symptoms is longer than that of Brief psychotic disorder, and there is no evidence of substance abuse to suggest Substance-induced psychosis. Schizophreniform disorder would require symptoms to be present for at least 1 month but less than 6 months, and the patient has been experiencing symptoms for 8 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of delusions and auditory hallucinations, which are consistent with the diagnosis of schizophrenia disorder. The symptoms have been present for over 6 months, ruling out brief psychotic disorder. There is no indication of substance use, ruling out substance-induced psychosis. Schizophreniform disorder is a diagnosis given when symptoms are present for less than 6 months, which is not the case with this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing hallucinations, delusions, and odd behavior, which are all symptoms of schizophrenia. The duration of symptoms is also more than 6 months, which rules out brief psychotic disorder and schizophreniform disorder. Negative urine toxicology test rules out substance-induced psychosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the preoccupation with school and job, odd behavior, auditory hallucinations, and paranoid delusions, are indicative of schizophrenia disorder. All other options have a time duration criteria that the symptoms do not meet.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, particularly the auditory hallucinations, delusions of persecution, and odd behavior, are consistent with Schizophrenia disorder. The duration of symptoms (8 months) also fits with this diagnosis, whereas Brief psychotic disorder has a duration of less than 1 month. Substance-induced psychosis would require a positive urine toxicology test. Schizophreniform disorder has a shorter duration of symptoms (1-6 months) and does not require impaired social or occupational functioning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is exhibiting symptoms of paranoid delusions, auditory hallucinations, and disorganized thinking, which are consistent with schizophrenia disorder. The duration of symptoms is more than 6 months, indicating that it is not a brief psychotic disorder. There is no evidence of substance use, ruling out substance-induced psychosis. Schizophreniform disorder has a duration of more than 1 month but less than 6 months, which is not consistent with this patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of schizophrenia, including hallucinations, delusions, and odd behavior. The duration of symptoms for 8 months indicates a diagnosis of schizophrenia rather than brief psychotic disorder or schizophreniform disorder. There is no evidence of substance use or abuse to suggest substance-induced psychosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest schizophrenia, including hearing voices and delusions of persecution. The symptoms have lasted for more than 6 months, which rules out brief psychotic disorder. Normal test results suggest that the symptoms are not caused by substance abuse or withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits negative symptoms of schizophrenia, including anxiety, preoccupation with thoughts, odd behavior, and auditory hallucinations. The belief that he is being targeted for death is a paranoid delusion, which is also common in schizophrenia. The symptoms have persisted for more than 6 months, meeting the criteria for schizophrenia. Substance-induced psychosis and brief psychotic disorder have a shorter duration of symptoms, and there is no evidence of substance use in this patient. Schizophreniform disorder is a provisional diagnosis for patients with symptoms of schizophrenia that last between 1 and 6 months but this patient has been symptomatic for more than 8 months.
